base_note.note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT - INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY

PATIENT: William O'Brien
MRN: 1808730  
DOB: 03/17/1955
AGE: 69
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 2025-04-30

SURGEON: Dr. David Chen, MD
ASSISTANT: Dr. Katherine Wong, MD (IP Fellow)
ANESTHESIOLOGIST: Dr. Paul Martinez, MD
FACILITY: Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Fractured right mainstem bronchus self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same; stent granulation tissue ingrowth

PROCEDURES PERFORMED:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy with stent removal
2. Bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial granulation tissue using APC

INDICATION: 69-year-old male with history of esophageal cancer status post esophagectomy complicated by recurrent stricture of airway fistula 18 months ago for which a covered SEMS was placed in the right mainstem bronchus. Recent CT showed stent fracture with proximal wire protruding into the trachea. Patient symptomatic with worsening cough and hemoptysis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, jet ventilation

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:
Under general anesthesia, the patient was intubated with a 12mm Bryan-Dumon ventilating rigid bronchoscope. Examination of the trachea revealed the fractured proximal portion of the right mainstem SEMS protruding approximately 1.5cm into the distal trachea. The fractured wire ends were sharp and had caused mucosal injury with surrounding granulation tissue formation.

A flexible bronchoscope was passed through the rigid scope to examine beyond the stent. The stent lumen was narrowed by approximately 40% due to granulation tissue ingrowth at the proximal end. The distal right bronchus intermedius appeared patent.

The granulation tissue was treated with APC (ERBE VIO, 30W, Effect 2) at the proximal stent margin, achieving adequate hemostasis and improving visualization.

Using a combination of rigid optical forceps and alligator forceps, the proximal edge of the stent was grasped. The stent was collapsed using the forceps in a rolling fashion and withdrawn en bloc through the rigid bronchoscope.

Inspection of the airway post-removal revealed:
- Mild residual granulation tissue at the former stent site (treated with APC)
- No perforation or significant bleeding
- Bronchus intermedius patent
- Right upper, middle, and lower lobe orifices patent

Final inspection showed no debris, no significant bleeding, patent airways bilaterally. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

SPECIMENS: None (stent sent to pathology for documentation)

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: 15mL

DISPOSITION: Same day discharge anticipated. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks to assess granulation tissue recurrence.

Dr. David Chen, MD
Dr. Katherine Wong, MD

registry_entry.primary_indication: Fractured right mainstem SEMS with granulation tissue

evidence.primary_indication: Fractured SEMS with proximal wire protrusion and granulation tissue

code_rationales.31635: Bronchoscopy with removal of foreign body (fractured SEMS stent). Stent removal codes with 31635 when stent has become displaced/fractured and requires extraction similar to FB removal.
code_rationales.31641: Bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial lesion (granulation tissue) using APC at the stent site.

coding_review.overall_assessment: Fractured stent removal is appropriately coded as FB removal (31635). Granulation tissue destruction (31641) is separately reportable when distinct service performed.

cpt_codes.description: Bronchoscopy; with removal of foreign body
Bronchoscopy; with destruction of tumor or relief of stenosis by any method

changes: Populated registry_entry.billing from ip_coding_billing.v2_7 for CPT codes 31635, 31641; total_work_rvu=8.67, total_rvu=13.94 (facility).

variations.note_text:
INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY PROCEDURE DOCUMENTATION
============================================================

PATIENT IDENTIFICATION AND DEMOGRAPHICS
----------------------------------------
Patient: As documented
Medical Record Number: 7940892
Date of Birth: 03/17/1956
Age at Procedure: 69 years
Procedure Date: N/A

CLINICAL INDICATION AND PREOPERATIVE ASSESSMENT
----------------------------------------
The patient presented with fractured right mainstem sems with granulation tissue. Following comprehensive multidisciplinary evaluation and informed consent discussion detailing procedural risks, benefits, and alternatives, the patient elected to proceed with the proposed intervention.

PROCEDURAL METHODOLOGY AND TECHNIQUE
----------------------------------------

Airway Stent:
Airway stent deployment was executed with fluoroscopic and bronchoscopic guidance to ensure optimal positioning and mucosal apposition. 
Tumor Destruction:


INTRAPROCEDURAL FINDINGS
----------------------------------------
Detailed airway examination was performed with findings as documented in the procedural narrative.


POSTPROCEDURAL ASSESSMENT AND DISPOSITION
----------------------------------------
The procedure was completed without immediate complications. The patient demonstrated hemodynamic stability throughout and was transferred to the recovery area in satisfactory condition.

PROCEDURAL CODING DOCUMENTATION
----------------------------------------
Current Procedural Terminology Codes: 31635, 31641

This documentation has been prepared in accordance with institutional standards for procedural documentation and coding compliance.

variations.note_text:
On None, None, a 68-year-old male (MRN 4026525), underwent bronchoscopic evaluation for Fractured right mainstem SEMS with granulation tissue. The patient received General and the procedure was performed in standard fashion. The procedure included placement of SEMS - Covered, and tumor destruction. 

On examination, the airways were systematically inspected. The visualized airways appeared patent without significant abnormality. The procedure was completed without immediate complications. 

The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the recovery area in stable condition. Specimens obtained were sent for appropriate analysis and results will be reviewed at follow-up. The preliminary assessment is benign. 

Procedural coding: 31635, 31641.

SURGEON: Dr. David Chen, MD
ASSISTANT: Dr. Katherine Wong, MD (IP Fellow)
ANESTHESIOLOGIST: Dr. Paul Martinez, MD
FACILITY: Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Fractured right mainstem bronchus self-expanding metallic stent (SEMS)

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same; stent granulation tissue ingrowth

PROCEDURES CARRIED OUT:
1. Rigid bronchoscopy with stent removal
2. Bronchoscopy with destruction of endobronchial granulation tissue using APC

INDICATION: 71-year-old male with history of esophageal cancer status post esophagectomy complicated by recurrent stricture of airway fistula 18 months ago for which a covered SEMS was installed in the right mainstem bronchus. Recent CT revealed stent fracture with proximal wire protruding into the trachea. Patient symptomatic with worsening cough and hemoptysis.

ANESTHESIA: General anesthesia, jet ventilation

DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:
Under general anesthesia, the patient was intubated with a 12mm Bryan-Dumon ventilating rigid bronchoscope. Examination of the trachea revealed the fractured proximal portion of the right mainstem SEMS protruding approximately 1.5cm into the distal trachea. The fractured wire ends were sharp and had caused mucosal injury with surrounding granulation tissue formation.

A flexible bronchoscope was passed through the rigid scope to examine beyond the stent. The stent lumen was narrowed by approximately 40% due to granulation tissue ingrowth at the proximal end. The distal right bronchus intermedius appeared navigable.

The granulation tissue was treated with APC (ERBE VIO, 30W, Effect 2) at the proximal stent margin, achieving adequate hemostasis and improving visualization.

Using a combination of rigid optical forceps and alligator forceps, the proximal edge of the stent was grasped. The stent was collapsed using the forceps in a rolling fashion and withdrawn en bloc through the rigid bronchoscope.

Inspection of the airway post-removal revealed:
- Mild residual granulation tissue at the former stent site (treated with APC)
- No perforation or significant bleeding
- Bronchus intermedius navigable
- Right upper, middle, and lower lobe orifices navigable

Final inspection revealed no debris, no significant bleeding, navigable airways bilaterally. The patient was extubated and transferred to PACU in stable condition.

SPECIMENS: None (stent sent to pathology for documentation)

COMPLICATIONS: None

EBL: 15mL

DISPOSITION: Same day discharge anticipated. Follow-up bronchoscopy in 6 weeks to assess granulation tissue recurrence.

Dr. David Chen, MD
Dr. Katherine Wong, MD
